How is this hub maturing relative to its global peers, and what lies ahead on the road to sustainable scale?</div></div></div></section><main data-layer-region="article-body" class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-xxl"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-1 mdc-u-grid-col-md-12"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-md-end-12 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-3 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-11"><div class="mdc-o-content-body mck-u-dropcap"><div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="DownloadsSidebar_mck-c-downloads-sidebar__iFmyt mck-o-xs-right-span"><div data-layer-region="downloads-right-rail"><h3 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-c-heading--title___5qyOB_990311c mdc-c-heading--border___K8dj3_990311c">DOWNLOADS</h3><div><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" href="#/download/%2F~%2Fmedia%2Fmckinsey%2Findustries%2Flife%20sciences%2Four%20insights%2Fthe%20uk%20biotech%20sector%20the%20path%20to%20global%20leadership%2Fthe-uk-biotech-sector-the-path-to-global-leadership_vf.pdf%3FshouldIndex%3Dfalse" class="DownloadsSidebar_mck-c-downloads-sidebar__download-link__fPqFQ mdc-c-link___lBbY1_990311c" target="_self" data-layer-event-prefix="Download Link" data-layer-action="click" data-layer-report-type="Article" data-layer-file-name="the-uk-biotech-sector-the-path-to-global-leadership_vf" data-layer-report-name="the-uk-biotech-sector-the-path-to-global-leadership_vf>Article"><span data-component="mdc-c-icon" class="mdc-c-icon___oi7ef_990311c mdc-c-icon--size-md___yi5fA_990311c mck-download-icon"></span><span class="mdc-c-link__label___Pfqtd_990311c">Article (11 pages)</span></a></div></div></div></div>
<p><strong>The global biotech sector </strong>is flourishing. COVID-19 vaccine success stories like the Pfizer and BioNTech partnership helped highlight the biotech industry’s significant impact in advancing healthcare. Private and public biotech funding, including global venture capital (VC) investments, deals, and IPOs, reached all-time highs in 2020. The surge in financing helped the global biotech sector outperform its sister industry, pharmaceuticals, and the consumer goods and technology sectors. And despite a brief downturn at the start of 2020, the average growth in UK biotechs’ share price was 32 percent, surpassing European biotechs (22 percent) and US biotechs (2 percent), and only trailing China’s 99 percent.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="6ad5980f-6812-4f0c-8c48-22f0970a3711"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="6ad5980f-6812-4f0c-8c48-22f0970a3711" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Based on findings from Corporate Performance Analytics by McKinsey and S&P Global.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<h2>The United Kingdom leads Europe in discovery research and life-science start-up funding</h2>
<p>Our <a href="/industries/life-sciences/our-insights/infographic-the-mckinsey-biotech-innovation-index">Biotech Innovation Index</a> assesses the biotech sector on four indicators:</p>

<ol>
    <li>Discovery: scientific publications and issued patents</li>
    <li>Translation: formation of new biotech companies and early-stage capital raised</li>
    <li>Growth capital: average amount of late-stage and public-equity rounds</li>
    <li>Impact: product approvals</li>
</ol>
<p>The Biotech Innovation Index reveals some interesting trends for the UK biotech sector. We supplemented the analysis by interviewing top UK biotech CEOs for additional insights into market drivers. </p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="light" data-module-background="lightest-grey" data-module-category="" data-module-gradient-position="bottom-right" data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>The UK biotech sector survived Brexit (so far) and thrived during the COVID-19 pandemic</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p><strong>During our discussions</strong> with biotech CEOs, we expected to hear that the dual disruption of Brexit and the COVID-19 pandemic had created a perfect storm, buffeting the UK biotech sector and impeding its progress versus other countries. </p>
<p>The pandemic challenged pharmaceutical companies’ established clinical develop­ment models and was especially hard on biotechs without the resources to rapidly transition to remote trials. The United Kingdom has endured sustained lockdowns, pressures on the National Health Service, and resources reallocated to the rapid COVID-19 vaccine rollout in 2021. However, our analysis indicates that biotech weathered the storm of the pandemic relatively well <a href="/industries/life-sciences/our-insights/whats-ahead-for-biotech-another-wave-or-low-tide">compared with other sectors</a>. UK biotechs raised £2.8 billion in 2020, a significant injection of capital into the market. Already adapted to working remotely with their international collaborators, UK-based biotechs got clinical trials back on track by pivoting to countries that were still open, such as Australia. </p>
<p>Similarly, Brexit appears to have had a limited near-term impact. Every CEO we spoke to said they had begun planning for a worst-case scenario in 2016, so the immediate effect on January 1, 2021, was negligible. However, in the long term, Brexit could challenge the United Kingdom’s long-standing position as an easy place to cultivate talent by disrupting the international talent funnel into academia and the industry. The chemistry, manufacturing, and controls and lab tech services industries might drain talent from London to the European Medicine Agency’s new headquarters in Amsterdam. Similarly, access to funding and EU grants will be curtailed, affecting companies that had relied on them. </p>
<p>Nonetheless, the executives we spoke to said systemic challenges facing the UK biotech sector—such as those identified in our analysis—pose a greater risk than Brexit or COVID-19. </p></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Among the four measures, UK biotech companies have outperformed their global peers in the Discovery index (Exhibit 1). Growth capital has also been impressive when considering the dual challenges of the COVID-19 pandemic and Brexit (see sidebar, “The UK biotech sector survived Brexit (so far) and thrived during the COVID-19 pandemic”). Overall, the United Kingdom is one of the most active biotech hubs globally, lagging behind only the United States. However, our Biotech Innovation Index analysis and CEO discussions indicate that, despite producing world-leading science, the United Kingdom struggles in Translation and Impact, that is, converting research into intellectual property and commercial products.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 1</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/life%20sciences/our%20insights/the%20uk%20biotech%20sector%20the%20path%20to%20global%20leadership/svgz-uk-biotech-v13-ex1.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="The UK biotech sector’s main challenge remains translating world-class science into commercialized products." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/life%20sciences/our%20insights/the%20uk%20biotech%20sector%20the%20path%20to%20global%20leadership/svgz-uk-biotech-v13-ex1.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>In our interviews with UK biotech CEOs, they shared that US market entry is critical to success in the current environment. They face an uphill battle for talent because the United Kingdom lacks the close-knit community that US biotech CEOs rely on to grow their companies. </p>
<p>To better understand the complexity of the UK biotech sector, whether its current trajectory is sustainable, and how it could raise its global standing, we provide an in-depth look at each of the Biotech Innovation Indexes.</p>
<div data-module-category="" class="PullQuote_mck-c-pullquote__DbaQ5 mck-o-lg-center" style="transform: translate(0px, 35px); opacity: 0;"><blockquote data-component="mdc-c-blockquote" class="PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote__6n21p PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote--hide-quotes__CpGpg mdc-c-blockquote mdc-c-blockquote--is-quotes___TozKo_990311c"><p>Our analysis indicates that biotech weathered the storm of the pandemic relatively well compared with other sectors. UK biotechs raised £2.8 billion in 2020, a significant injection of capital into the market.</p></blockquote></div>
<h4>Discovery index</h4>
<p>The United Kingdom has always had a reputation for scientific excellence. The country produces 29 percent of European scientific journal publications. It ranks fourth on the <a href="https://www.wipo.int/edocs/pubdocs/en/wipo_pub_gii_2021.pdf">Global Innovation Index</a> with 116,815 jobs created and R&D spending projected to rise to 2.4 percent by 2027.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="43549bf3-7cef-41ee-b02c-f6788477c79e"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="43549bf3-7cef-41ee-b02c-f6788477c79e" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>Life sciences industrial strategy: A report to the government from the life sciences sector</em>, UK Office for Life Sciences, August 30, 2017, gov.uk. </span></span></span></a></span> It boasts world-class universities, 28 Nobel Prize laureates in physiology and medicine, and a tradition of sustained academic excellence in the life sciences. The <em>Times Higher Education</em> <a href="https://www.timeshighereducation.com/world-university-rankings/2022/world-ranking#!/page/0/length/25/sort_by/rank/sort_order/asc/cols/stats">World University Rankings 2022</a> ranks Oxford first, Cambridge fifth, and Imperial College London 12th. The United Kingdom leads its European peers in total life-sciences publications and leads the world in publications per billion dollars of GDP (Exhibit 2).</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 2</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/life%20sciences/our%20insights/the%20uk%20biotech%20sector%20the%20path%20to%20global%20leadership/svgz-uk-biotech-v13-ex2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Although UK biotechs lead on publications per billion dollars of GDP, they lag behind other European countries in granting patents." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/life%20sciences/our%20insights/the%20uk%20biotech%20sector%20the%20path%20to%20global%20leadership/svgz-uk-biotech-v13-ex2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>A critical first step to maintaining a strong UK biotech pipeline is ensuring that discoveries are patented. The United Kingdom has made significant progress on this front by enabling technology transfer from leading universities. From 2015 to 2019, there was a 5 percent growth in UK patents granted compared with European peers. But the United Kingdom falls behind the United States, China, and several of its European counterparts in the number of patents granted per scientific publication; eight per 1,000 versus 54 in the United States, 70 in Switzerland, and 72 in China. <a href="https://www.ft.com/content/fd038300-f09a-4afc-9f7d-c0e3d6965243">Published research</a> suggests that British universities often demand an equity share of 25 to 50 percent on founding, compared with 10 percent at leading academic institutions in the United States and other countries.</p>
<h4>Translation index</h4>
<p>The number of new UK-based biotech start-ups decreased by 72 percent, from 79 to 22, between 2015 to 2017 and 2018 to 2020. However, the United Kingdom still led Europe in launching the most companies, 22 of 70, from 2018 to 2020. And today, 387 of the 1,382 biotechs in Europe—more than 30 percent—originated in the United Kingdom (Exhibit 3).
</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 3</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/life%20sciences/our%20insights/the%20uk%20biotech%20sector%20the%20path%20to%20global%20leadership/svgz-uk-biotech-v14-ex3-v2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="The United Kingdom bests other European countries in the number of new biotech start-ups and funding for those companies." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/life%20sciences/our%20insights/the%20uk%20biotech%20sector%20the%20path%20to%20global%20leadership/svgz-uk-biotech-v14-ex3-v2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>The United Kingdom is either the outright leader or among the top three in Europe in the total number of companies pursuing novel modalities—such as advanced therapy medicinal products and immuno­therapies—and focusing on challenging therapeutic areas, such as oncology and the central nervous system. The UK government has invested heavily in programs to maintain the United Kingdom as the largest biotech hub in Europe; the <a href="https://catapult.org.uk/">Catapult Network</a>, a collection of independent not-for-profit centers that bridge the gap between research and business in <a href="https://ct.catapult.org.uk/">cell and gene therapy</a>, is one such program. </p>
<!-- -->
<p>Although the United Kingdom is on par with Europe with regard to average early-stage funding ($21 million per UK biotech versus $20 million per European biotech), both still lag significantly behind the United States ($36 million) and China ($46 million). UK biotech CEOs say that it is challenging to access VC funding because specialized biotech investors who can accurately assess investment opportunities are scarce in the United Kingdom compared with the United States. Also, several high-profile UK biotech start-ups that failed “put people off” the space. There is a relatively higher level of comfort investing in US biotech. With the lower level of industry experience at the average UK biotech company, UK biotech executives are often less effective at communicating value and winning over savvy biotech-focused investors. </p>
<h4>Growth capital index</h4>
<p>Biotech companies in the United Kingdom outperform their European peers in securing early-stage funding but raise fewer rounds at a smaller average size than start-ups in the United States and China. Compared with European firms, UK biotechs raise less late-stage financing that would enable them to scale operations without going public on a US exchange. Since 2018, only two drugs developed by UK biotech companies have been approved by the European Medicines Agency (EMA) or US Food and Drug Administration (FDA). But as more therapies reach the market, UK start-ups may attract more mezzanine financing. </p>
<p>From 2018 to 2020, UK start-ups raised $3.6 billion, 20 percent more venture and public-equity financing than they did from 2015 to 2017 (Exhibit 4). Some UK biotech IPOs raised more than $100 million, breaking previous records. Kymab, an immunology company valued at $1.1 billion, was recently acquired by Sanofi. Immunocore launched on Nasdaq at a value of more than $250 million, Freeline Therapeutics and Allergy Therapeutics over
$150 million, and Compass Pathways and Vaccitech at more than $100 million.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 4</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/life%20sciences/our%20insights/the%20uk%20biotech%20sector%20the%20path%20to%20global%20leadership/svgz-uk-biotech-v13-ex4.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="UK-based firms have raised more total venture capital and IPO funding than other biotech start-ups across Europe." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/life%20sciences/our%20insights/the%20uk%20biotech%20sector%20the%20path%20to%20global%20leadership/svgz-uk-biotech-v13-ex4.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>Despite leading Europe on total financing raised and the average size of early- and late-stage VC rounds and IPOs, the UK biotech sector struggled to fund later-stage development. There were significantly fewer late-stage deals, with no UK biotechs completing series D financing, and only one a series E for $12 million, between 2018 and 2020 (Exhibit 5). Biotech CEOs explained that this is because more UK start-ups choose to go public with an IPO on US exchanges, where the average IPO size is significantly higher than in the United Kingdom or Europe. European firms more often prefer to scale their operations and pursue acquisition by a large pharmaceutical company than go to public-equity markets. </p>
<!-- -->
<p>UK biotechs have seen a 160 percent increase in average IPO size. However, they still raise less total capital from IPOs than in other countries: $0.9 billion from 2018 to 2020 versus $2 billion in Europe, $29.2 billion in the United States, and $15.3 billion in China. The total number of IPOs for UK biotechs declined 40 percent between 2018 and 2020, indicating that this exit strategy is becoming more difficult. CEOs explained that early-stage investors are wary of IPOs and UK CFOs often lack the expertise to navigate the complexities of a Nasdaq launch. </p>
<div data-module-category="" class="PullQuote_mck-c-pullquote__DbaQ5 mck-o-lg-center" style="transform: translate(0px, 35px); opacity: 0;"><blockquote data-component="mdc-c-blockquote" class="PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote__6n21p PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote--hide-quotes__CpGpg mdc-c-blockquote mdc-c-blockquote--is-quotes___TozKo_990311c"><p>UK biotechs have seen a 160 percent increase in average IPO size. However, they still raise less total capital from IPOs than in other countries.</p></blockquote></div>
<h4>Impact index</h4>
<p>UK CEOs report that the relative size of the US market compels most companies to launch there first. As a result, UK biotechs often require US-based leadership and operations. While the United Kingdom has deep scientific expertise, it lacks a pool of experienced managers, such as CMOs, CFOs, market-access experts, and regulatory professionals, who can commercialize biotech products. UK biotech CEOs told us they increasingly fill gaps by recruiting the best talent where they find it. If that means opening a small, local office outside the United Kingdom to accommodate critical personnel, they adapt their business accordingly. Executives with launch experience tend to be based in the United States and are in high demand.</p>
<p>Although the EMA or FDA have approved only two products from UK biotechs since 2018, CEOs explained that’s because UK companies often out-license their assets to large pharma. Globally, there is a trend in biotech toward launches being the companies’ first; 27 percent between 2016 and 2018. Of the 39 new therapies expected to launch by 2026 globally, more than half will be their company’s first. </p>
<p>The UK biotech CEOs we spoke to called for a global perspective on success. While local factors primarily influence the discovery, translation, and growth capital indexes, impact is global. It flows from recognized science, a global investor base, and delivering products to the patients who need them.</p>
<h2>How the UK biotech sector can become a global leader</h2>
<p>The CEOs we spoke to offered a remarkably consistent blueprint for how the UK biotech sector can sustain its dominance in Europe and potentially grow into a global leader. They called on UK biotechs to change their behavior, leverage their uniquely data-rich environment, and increase collaboration and collective growth. And they advised companies to broaden their vision from successful UK biotech to successful global biotech based in the United Kingdom. Here are four ways to do that: </p>
<ol>
    <li><strong>Build relationships with US investors
    </strong>
    <p>UK biotech CEOs are increasingly turning to the US IPO market to scale their businesses. </p>
    <p>There, they compete directly with US-based, and increasingly, China-based, biotechs for investment capital. The intense competition may require UK biotechs to be more strategic in choosing which revenue opportunities to pursue and accelerating the development timeline. There is no one way to secure investors, but the following tactics can help:</p>
    <ul>
        <li>Invest time building relationships with a US-based investor network in relevant therapeutic areas and technologies, and consider recruiting US-based talent for the CFO, CMO, and COO roles.</li>
        <li>Demonstrate a deep understanding of the US market opportunity and what it takes to bring a profitable, reimbursable product to market.</li>
        <li>Set ambitious goals for the company and request sufficient funding to deliver on these ambitions at speed.</li>
    </ul>
    </li>
    <li><strong>Adapt to win the global race for life-sciences talent
    </strong>
    <p>As the global footprint of larger UK biotechs expands and the ongoing war for talent intensifies, companies might benefit from the following:</p>
    <ul>
        <li>
        Attract and retain UK discovery and development talent to support maturing portfolios.</li>
        <li>Establish a US base to house certain key executives, such as CFOs.</li>
        <li>Change the traditional UK perception of success and failure; a CEO from a failed biotech has valuable experience to bring to the next start-up.</li>
        <li>Consider siting clinical or regulatory operations in the European Union, close to senior talent and potentially in lower-cost markets.</li>
    </ul>
    </li>
    <li><strong>Tap into UK life-sciences resources
    </strong>
    <p>In recent years, there have been significant efforts across the UK life-sciences sector to help biotechs bridge the “valley of death” between academic innovation and commercialization. The United Kingdom’s <a href="https://www.hdruk.org/">Digital Innovation Hub</a> has transformed local data from the <a href="https://www.ukbiobank.ac.uk/">UK Biobank</a>, <a href="https://www.genomicsengland.co.uk/">Genomics England</a>, and <a href="https://digital.nhs.uk/data">NHS Data</a> into a “research-ready” format. These resources could support target identification, indication finding, in silico drug discovery for early-stage companies, and indication expansion or safety expansion for products in development. Companies could also analyze this real-world data to produce real-world evidence that characterizes disease burden and supports reimbursement. Many valuable and unique UK resources remain underutilized, creating the opportunity for UK biotechs to do the following:</p>
    <ul>
        <li>
        Invest in advanced analytics to utilize local data resources because access via third parties may be prohibitively expensive.</li>
        <li>Leverage “omic” data sets (such as UK Biobank, Genomics England, and <a href="https://bioresource.nihr.ac.uk/">NIHR BioResource</a>) to accelerate the development of precision medicines.</li>
        <li>Partner with players such as <a href="https://www.nhsx.nhs.uk/">NHSx</a> to conduct digitized or virtualized trials.</li>
        <li>Utilize the talent-finding resources at the <a href="https://advancedtherapiesapprenticeships.co.uk/">Advanced Therapies Apprenticeship Community</a> program or seek advice from the 200 cell and gene therapy experts at the Cell and Gene Therapy Catapult.</li>
    </ul>
    </li>
    <li><strong>Strengthen the UK biotech community
    </strong>
    <p>As the UK biotech sector matures, there is potential to create the same “virtuous innovation circle” seen in other hubs such as Boston and Silicon Valley. Emulating these more established business clusters, UK biotech CEOs and senior executives can seek opportunities to do the following:</p>
    <ul>
        <li>
        Share experiences and learnings on how to bring UK biotechs to scale on a global stage.</li>
        <li>Coach CEOs earlier in the innovation funnel on how to shape their fundraising strategy, refine their investment cases, and work with investors and partners.</li>
        <li>Cooperate with industry associations to convey the vibrancy of the UK biotech sector to foreign-based investors and to advocate within the United Kingdom for the policies and legislation needed to boost the sector’s growth.</li>
    </ul>
    </li>
</ol></div><div class="container-placeholder"></div></div></div><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-xl"><section role="contentinfo" data-layer-region="article-about-authors" class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 AboutAuthor_mck-c-about-author__nRJzu"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-md-end-12 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-3 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-11"><h5 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-c-heading--title___5qyOB_990311c mdc-c-heading--border___K8dj3_990311c mdc-u-align-center">About the author(s)</h5><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-8 mck-u-links-inline mck-u-links-inline--secondary mdc-u-mt-5"><div><p><strong>Mayank Bhandari</strong> is a consultant in McKinsey’s London office, where <a href="/our-people/alex-devereson"><strong>Alex Devereson</strong></a> and <strong>Rachel Moss</strong> are partners, and where <a href="/our-people/shail-thaker"><strong>Shail Thaker</strong></a> is a senior partner. <strong>David Cooney</strong> is a consultant in the Dublin office.</p>

We supplemented the analysis by interviewing top UK biotech CEOs for additional insights into market drivers. \u003c/p\u003e\n[[Sidebar 1]]\n\u003cp\u003eAmong the four measures, UK biotech companies have outperformed their global peers in the Discovery index (Exhibit 1). Growth capital has also been impressive when considering the dual challenges of the COVID-19 pandemic and Brexit (see sidebar, \u0026ldquo;The UK biotech sector survived Brexit (so far) and thrived during the COVID-19 pandemic\u0026rdquo;). Overall, the United Kingdom is one of the most active biotech hubs globally, lagging behind only the United States. However, our Biotech Innovation Index analysis and CEO discussions indicate that, despite producing world-leading science, the United Kingdom struggles in Translation and Impact, that is, converting research into intellectual property and commercial products.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 1]]\n\u003cp\u003eIn our interviews with UK biotech CEOs, they shared that US market entry is critical to success in the current environment. They face an uphill battle for talent because the United Kingdom lacks the close-knit community that US biotech CEOs rely on to grow their companies. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo better understand the complexity of the UK biotech sector, whether its current trajectory is sustainable, and how it could raise its global standing, we provide an in-depth look at each of the Biotech Innovation Indexes.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[PullQuote 1]]\n\u003ch4\u003eDiscovery index\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe United Kingdom has always had a reputation for scientific excellence. The country produces 29 percent of European scientific journal publications. It ranks fourth on the \u003ca href=\"https://www.wipo.int/edocs/pubdocs/en/wipo_pub_gii_2021.pdf\"\u003eGlobal Innovation Index\u003c/a\u003e with 116,815 jobs created and R\u0026amp;D spending projected to rise to 2.4 percent by 2027.[[Footnote 2]] It boasts world-class universities, 28 Nobel Prize laureates in physiology and medicine, and a tradition of sustained academic excellence in the life sciences. The \u003cem\u003eTimes Higher Education\u003c/em\u003e \u003ca href=\"https://www.timeshighereducation.com/world-university-rankings/2022/world-ranking#!/page/0/length/25/sort_by/rank/sort_order/asc/cols/stats\"\u003eWorld University Rankings 2022\u003c/a\u003e ranks Oxford first, Cambridge fifth, and Imperial College London 12th. The United Kingdom leads its European peers in total life-sciences publications and leads the world in publications per billion dollars of GDP (Exhibit 2).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 2]]\n\u003cp\u003eA critical first step to maintaining a strong UK biotech pipeline is ensuring that discoveries are patented. The United Kingdom has made significant progress on this front by enabling technology transfer from leading universities. From 2015 to 2019, there was a 5 percent growth in UK patents granted compared with European peers. But the United Kingdom falls behind the United States, China, and several of its European counterparts in the number of patents granted per scientific publication; eight per 1,000 versus 54 in the United States, 70 in Switzerland, and 72 in China. \u003ca href=\"https://www.ft.com/content/fd038300-f09a-4afc-9f7d-c0e3d6965243\"\u003ePublished research\u003c/a\u003e suggests that British universities often demand an equity share of 25 to 50 percent on founding, compared with 10 percent at leading academic institutions in the United States and other countries.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eTranslation index\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe number of new UK-based biotech start-ups decreased by 72 percent, from 79 to 22, between 2015 to 2017 and 2018 to 2020. However, the United Kingdom still led Europe in launching the most companies, 22 of 70, from 2018 to 2020. And today, 387 of the 1,382 biotechs in Europe\u0026mdash;more than 30 percent\u0026mdash;originated in the United Kingdom (Exhibit 3).\n\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 3]]\n\u003cp\u003eThe United Kingdom is either the outright leader or among the top three in Europe in the total number of companies pursuing novel modalities\u0026mdash;such as advanced therapy medicinal products and immuno­therapies\u0026mdash;and focusing on challenging therapeutic areas, such as oncology and the central nervous system. The UK government has invested heavily in programs to maintain the United Kingdom as the largest biotech hub in Europe; the \u003ca href=\"https://catapult.org.uk/\"\u003eCatapult Network\u003c/a\u003e, a collection of independent not-for-profit centers that bridge the gap between research and business in \u003ca href=\"https://ct.catapult.org.uk/\"\u003ecell and gene therapy\u003c/a\u003e, is one such program. \u003c/p\u003e\n[[MostPopularArticles 5]]\n\u003cp\u003eAlthough the United Kingdom is on par with Europe with regard to average early-stage funding ($21 million per UK biotech versus $20 million per European biotech), both still lag significantly behind the United States ($36 million) and China ($46 million). UK biotech CEOs say that it is challenging to access VC funding because specialized biotech investors who can accurately assess investment opportunities are scarce in the United Kingdom compared with the United States. But as more therapies reach the market, UK start-ups may attract more mezzanine financing. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFrom 2018 to 2020, UK start-ups raised $3.6 billion, 20 percent more venture and public-equity financing than they did from 2015 to 2017 (Exhibit 4). Some UK biotech IPOs raised more than $100 million, breaking previous records. Kymab, an immunology company valued at $1.1 billion, was recently acquired by Sanofi. Immunocore launched on Nasdaq at a value of more than $250 million, Freeline Therapeutics and Allergy Therapeutics over\n$150 million, and Compass Pathways and Vaccitech at more than $100 million.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 4]]\n\u003cp\u003eDespite leading Europe on total financing raised and the average size of early- and late-stage VC rounds and IPOs, the UK biotech sector struggled to fund later-stage development. There were significantly fewer late-stage deals, with no UK biotechs completing series D financing, and only one a series E for $12 million, between 2018 and 2020 (Exhibit 5). Biotech CEOs explained that this is because more UK start-ups choose to go public with an IPO on US exchanges, where the average IPO size is significantly higher than in the United Kingdom or Europe. European firms more often prefer to scale their operations and pursue acquisition by a large pharmaceutical company than go to public-equity markets. \u003c/p\u003e\n[[Ceros 1]]\n\u003cp\u003eUK biotechs have seen a 160 percent increase in average IPO size. However, they still raise less total capital from IPOs than in other countries: $0.9 billion from 2018 to 2020 versus $2 billion in Europe, $29.2 billion in the United States, and $15.3 billion in China. The total number of IPOs for UK biotechs declined 40 percent between 2018 and 2020, indicating that this exit strategy is becoming more difficult. CEOs explained that early-stage investors are wary of IPOs and UK CFOs often lack the expertise to navigate the complexities of a Nasdaq launch. \u003c/p\u003e\n[[PullQuote 2]]\n\u003ch4\u003eImpact index\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eUK CEOs report that the relative size of the US market compels most companies to launch there first. As a result, UK biotechs often require US-based leadership and operations. While the United Kingdom has deep scientific expertise, it lacks a pool of experienced managers, such as CMOs, CFOs, market-access experts, and regulatory professionals, who can commercialize biotech products. UK biotech CEOs told us they increasingly fill gaps by recruiting the best talent where they find it. If that means opening a small, local office outside the United Kingdom to accommodate critical personnel, they adapt their business accordingly. Executives with launch experience tend to be based in the United States and are in high demand.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAlthough the EMA or FDA have approved only two products from UK biotechs since 2018, CEOs explained that\u0026rsquo;s because UK companies often out-license their assets to large pharma. Globally, there is a trend in biotech toward launches being the companies\u0026rsquo; first; 27 percent between 2016 and 2018. Of the 39 new therapies expected to launch by 2026 globally, more than half will be their company\u0026rsquo;s first. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe UK biotech CEOs we spoke to called for a global perspective on success. While local factors primarily influence the discovery, translation, and growth capital indexes, impact is global. It flows from recognized science, a global investor base, and delivering products to the patients who need them.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eHow the UK biotech sector can become a global leader\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe CEOs we spoke to offered a remarkably consistent blueprint for how the UK biotech sector can sustain its dominance in Europe and potentially grow into a global leader. They called on UK biotechs to change their behavior, leverage their uniquely data-rich environment, and increase collaboration and collective growth. And they advised companies to broaden their vision from successful UK biotech to successful global biotech based in the United Kingdom. Here are four ways to do that: \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eBuild relationships with US investors\n    \u003c/strong\u003e\n    \u003cp\u003eUK biotech CEOs are increasingly turning to the US IPO market to scale their businesses. \u003c/p\u003e\n    \u003cp\u003eThere, they compete directly with US-based, and increasingly, China-based, biotechs for investment capital. The intense competition may require UK biotechs to be more strategic in choosing which revenue opportunities to pursue and accelerating the development timeline. There is no one way to secure investors, but the following tactics can help:\u003c/p\u003e\n    \u003cul\u003e\n        \u003cli\u003eInvest time building relationships with a US-based investor network in relevant therapeutic areas and technologies, and consider recruiting US-based talent for the CFO, CMO, and COO roles.\u003c/li\u003e\n        \u003cli\u003eDemonstrate a deep understanding of the US market opportunity and what it takes to bring a profitable, reimbursable product to market.\u003c/li\u003e\n        \u003cli\u003eSet ambitious goals for the company and request sufficient funding to deliver on these ambitions at speed.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003c/ul\u003e\n    \u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eAdapt to win the global race for life-sciences talent\n    \u003c/strong\u003e\n    \u003cp\u003eAs the global footprint of larger UK biotechs expands and the ongoing war for talent intensifies, companies might benefit from the following:\u003c/p\u003e\n    \u003cul\u003e\n        \u003cli\u003e\n        Attract and retain UK discovery and development talent to support maturing portfolios.\u003c/li\u003e\n        \u003cli\u003eEstablish a US base to house certain key executives, such as CFOs.\u003c/li\u003e\n        \u003cli\u003eChange the traditional UK perception of success and failure; a CEO from a failed biotech has valuable experience to bring to the next start-up.\u003c/li\u003e\n        \u003cli\u003eConsider siting clinical or regulatory operations in the European Union, close to senior talent and potentially in lower-cost markets.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003c/ul\u003e\n    \u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eTap into UK life-sciences resources\n    \u003c/strong\u003e\n    \u003cp\u003eIn recent years, there have been significant efforts across the UK life-sciences sector to help biotechs bridge the \u0026ldquo;valley of death\u0026rdquo; between academic innovation and commercialization. The United Kingdom\u0026rsquo;s \u003ca href=\"https://www.hdruk.org/\"\u003eDigital Innovation Hub\u003c/a\u003e has transformed local data from the \u003ca href=\"https://www.ukbiobank.ac.uk/\"\u003eUK Biobank\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href=\"https://www.genomicsengland.co.uk/\"\u003eGenomics England\u003c/a\u003e, and \u003ca href=\"https://digital.nhs.uk/data\"\u003eNHS Data\u003c/a\u003e into a \u0026ldquo;research-ready\u0026rdquo; format. These resources could support target identification, indication finding, in silico drug discovery for early-stage companies, and indication expansion or safety expansion for products in development. Companies could also analyze this real-world data to produce real-world evidence that characterizes disease burden and supports reimbursement. Many valuable and unique UK resources remain underutilized, creating the opportunity for UK biotechs to do the following:\u003c/p\u003e\n    \u003cul\u003e\n        \u003cli\u003e\n        Invest in advanced analytics to utilize local data resources because access via third parties may be prohibitively expensive.\u003c/li\u003e\n        \u003cli\u003eLeverage \u0026ldquo;omic\u0026rdquo; data sets (such as UK Biobank, Genomics England, and \u003ca href=\"https://bioresource.nihr.ac.uk/\"\u003eNIHR BioResource\u003c/a\u003e) to accelerate the development of precision medicines.\u003c/li\u003e\n        \u003cli\u003ePartner with players such as \u003ca href=\"https://www.nhsx.nhs.uk/\"\u003eNHSx\u003c/a\u003e to conduct digitized or virtualized trials.\u003c/li\u003e\n        \u003cli\u003eUtilize the talent-finding resources at the \u003ca href=\"https://advancedtherapiesapprenticeships.co.uk/\"\u003eAdvanced Therapies Apprenticeship Community\u003c/a\u003e program or seek advice from the 200 cell and gene therapy experts at the Cell and Gene Therapy Catapult.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003c/ul\u003e\n    \u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eStrengthen the UK biotech community\n    \u003c/strong\u003e\n    \u003cp\u003eAs the UK biotech sector matures, there is potential to create the same \u0026ldquo;virtuous innovation circle\u0026rdquo; seen in other hubs such as Boston and Silicon Valley. Emulating these more established business clusters, UK biotech CEOs and senior executives can seek opportunities to do the following:\u003c/p\u003e\n    \u003cul\u003e\n        \u003cli\u003e\n        Share experiences and learnings on how to bring UK biotechs to scale on a global stage.\u003c/li\u003e\n        \u003cli\u003eCoach CEOs earlier in the innovation funnel on how to shape their fundraising strategy, refine their investment cases, and work with investors and partners.\u003c/li\u003e\n        \u003cli\u003eCooperate with industry associations to convey the vibrancy of the UK biotech sector to foreign-based investors and to advocate within the United Kingdom for the policies and legislation needed to boost the sector\u0026rsquo;s growth.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003c/ul\u003e\n our discussions\u003c/strong\u003e with biotech CEOs, we expected to hear that the dual disruption of Brexit and the COVID-19 pandemic had created a perfect storm, buffeting the UK biotech sector and impeding its progress versus other countries. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe pandemic challenged pharmaceutical companies\u0026rsquo; established clinical develop­ment models and was especially hard on biotechs without the resources to rapidly transition to remote trials. The United Kingdom has endured sustained lockdowns, pressures on the National Health Service, and resources reallocated to the rapid COVID-19 vaccine rollout in 2021. However, our analysis indicates that biotech weathered the storm of the pandemic relatively well \u003ca href=\"/industries/life-sciences/our-insights/whats-ahead-for-biotech-another-wave-or-low-tide\"\u003ecompared with other sectors\u003c/a\u003e. UK biotechs raised \u0026pound;2.8 billion in 2020, a significant injection of capital into the market. Already adapted to working remotely with their international collaborators, UK-based biotechs got clinical trials back on track by pivoting to countries that were still open, such as Australia. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSimilarly, Brexit appears to have had a limited near-term impact. Every CEO we spoke to said they had begun planning for a worst-case scenario in 2016, so the immediate effect on January 1, 2021, was negligible. However, in the long term, Brexit could challenge the United Kingdom\u0026rsquo;s long-standing position as an easy place to cultivate talent by disrupting the international talent funnel into academia and the industry. The chemistry, manufacturing, and controls and lab tech services industries might drain talent from London to the European Medicine Agency\u0026rsquo;s new headquarters in Amsterdam. Similarly, access to funding and EU grants will be curtailed, affecting companies that had relied on them. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNonetheless, the executives we spoke to said systemic challenges facing the UK biotech sector\u0026mdash;such as those identified in our analysis\u0026mdash;pose a greater risk than Brexit or COVID-19.
